Award.AwardTitle: Investigating the Barriers to Retention and Tenure for Black and Hispanic Engineering Faculty at R1 Institutions

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration: The purpose of this project is to identify factors that facilitate or impede progress toward tenure for Black and Hispanic engineering faculty (BHEF) on the tenure track at four-year Research1 (R1) Institutions of Higher Education (IHE) and how those factors contribute to faculty retention and/or turnover. This project seeks to uncover how departments that do well in retaining BHEF might operate differently from those that do not. The objectives are to (a) empirically explore the link between faculty socialization and BHEF tenure and retention, (b) better understand the “push/pull” (i.e., promote/impede) factors that affect that relationship, and (c) how those factors look in IHEs/engineering departments that retain their BHEF when compared to those that do not. This research will provide greater insight into how to retain underrepresented BHEF in the critical field of engineering. When talented BHEF are tenured, institutions are better positioned to develop a diverse, globally competitive, next generation of engineers. This in turn, contributes to increased economic competitiveness in the United States. <br/> <br/>Scholars maintain that socialization (i.e., the norms and values transmitted) is largely responsible for the non-inclusive departmental environments that spur higher rates of attrition for underrepresented minority faculty. However, this theory has not been robustly examined. A sequential mixed methods design will be employed to address three research questions. Phase One explores, “What are the factors that facilitate and/or impede progress towards tenure among pre-tenured BHEF at four-year R1 institutions?” and includes a national survey to all professors of engineering at R1 higher education institutions nationally to determine the relationship between diversity climate and faculty turnover intentions. Diversity climate will be measured by the Diversity Climate Perceptions scale (Mor Barak et al., 1998) and the Diversity Promise scale (Chrobot-Mason, 2003), while turnover intentions will be measured by the TI-6 instrument (Shore & Martin, 1989). The initial results will be disaggregated by sub-disciplines, (e.g., civil, electrical) to determine any potential differences in engineering subfields. Phase Two addresses two research questions: “How do the factors that facilitate and/or impede progress towards tenure operate in contributing to faculty retention or turnover?” and “How do IHEs/engineering departments that retain BHEF socialize their faculty differently from those that do not?” The results of the phase one survey will be used to identify the sample of late pre-tenure professors (self-identified as Black or Hispanic) from which to recruit participants for follow-up interviews over a two-year period. The investigators will examine the rationale and factors influencing decisions to remain in or depart from the professoriate; and if they depart, where they have gone and what they plan to do. In addition to identifying supports and barriers to tenure for BHEF, this research is expected to reveal ways to mitigate the exclusionary effect of barriers to better sustain the diversification of engineering faculty, as well as provide insights to create inclusive IHE/departments.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of the project “Investigating the Barriers to Retention and Tenure for Black and Hispanic Engineering Faculty at R1 Institutions” was to determine the potential influence of diversity climate on Engineering faculty turnover intentions, and specifically identify factors that facilitate or impede progress toward tenure for pre-tenured Black and Hispanic engineering faculty (BHEF) at four-year “R1” Institutions. 

  

Research Questions and Methodological Approach  

 

RQ1. What are the factors that facilitate and/or impede progress towards tenure among pre-tenured Black and Hispanic engineering faculty (BHEF) at four-year “R1” Institutions? (Phase One – Survey) 

 

RQ2. How do the factors that facilitate and/or impede progress towards tenure operate in contributing to faculty retention or turnover?  (Phase Two – Follow-Up Interviews) 

 

RQ3. How do IHEs/engineering departments that retain BHEF socialize their faculty differently from those that do not?  (Phase Two – Follow-Up Interviews) 

 

Phase One included a national survey of all professors of engineering at R1 Institutions of Higher Education to determine the relationship between diversity climate and faculty turnover intentions (sub-analysis on BHEF with sample size permitting).  Diversity climate was measured by the Diversity Climate Perceptions scale (Mor Barak et al., 1998) and the Diversity Promise scale (Chrobot-Mason, 2003), while turnover intentions were measured by the TI-6 instrument (Shore & Martin, 1989). Power analysis suggested a minimum sample size of 73 for Phase One. We achieved a sample size of 1,161.  

 

In general, our results suggested that the Diversity Climate Survey appears to be measuring the engineering faculty’s perception of the diversity climate in their working institutions. While the use of the survey has been supported in the past for use in the business context, this study suggests its relevance for engineering faculty at R1 higher education institutions as well. The study also found evidence to support the importance of the diversity climate for URM/female faculty and for their turnover intentions. 

 

In Phase Two, the results of the Phase One survey provided a preliminary understanding of the issue and enabled us to identify the sample (n=16) of late pre-tenure BHEF (5th year and beyond) that we recruied for two years of follow-up interviews within Phase Two. We engaged in dialogue with the faculty to better understand their rationale for staying or leaving; any obstacles experienced or factors that would have changed their mind; and if they depart, where they have gone and what they plan to do in the future.  

 

For Phase 2, the qualitative portion of the study, we interviewed 16 BHEF over 2 years and found the following themes across the interviews: (1) COVID-19 tenure clock extensions were both a blessing and a curse, (2) there was a lack of tangible action demonstrating a commitment to diversity, equity, and inclusion, (3) participants felt that they incurred a “cultural tax” that increased the difficulty of their roles, and (4) the engineering work environment remains exclusive. Additional themes that we are still exploring include the varied intersectional experiences of specific subgroups within BHEF, the general faculty’s resistance, and hostility toward DEI (Diversity Equity and Inclusion) issues within engineering units, the ways that macro/microaggressions harm underrepresented minorities in the profession, and the continued BHEF pipeline challenges. 

 

INTELLECTUAL MERIT  

 

Socialization processes shape the work climate of an organization (Chao, 2014), which then further reinforces the organizational role expectations that may promote employee retention or turnover. Critical scholars maintain that socialization (i.e., the norms and values transmitted) is largely responsible for the non-inclusive departmental environments that spur higher rates of attrition for underrepresented minority faculty. However, this theory has not been robustly tested. Therefore, based on the literature, we developed and will employ Socialization to Tenure framework as our conceptual model to highlights how socialization serves as an explanatory and perpetuating agent that reinforces the work diversity climate that lead to the retention, turnover and eventual tenure outcomes.  

 

BROADER IMPACTS  

 

The broader impacts of this project are achieved through the research itself, which will provide greater insight into how to retain underrepresented BHEF in the critical field of engineering; progressing towards achieving the goal of full participation of underrepresented minorities in STEM. When talented BHEF are tenured, this puts the institution in position to develop a diverse, globally competitive, next generation of scholars. This in turn, contributes to increased economic competitiveness in the United States.
